snippet: The Tabqa Dam, Syria’s biggest, is considered a potent weapon in the battle for allegiances in the nearly two-year-old conflict.
abstract: Syrian insurgents and opposition activists say that rebel forces have taken control of country's largest hydroelectric dam, assertion that, if confirmed, would give them significant control over vital reservoir and what remains of sporadic power supplies in country.

byline.original: By HWAIDA SAAD and RICK GLADSTONE
byline.contributor: Hwaida Saad reported from Beirut, and Rick Gladstone from New York. Reporting was contributed by Anne Barnard in Beirut; Sebnem Arsu and David D. Kirkpatrick in Gaziantep, Turkey; and an employee of The New York Times in Damascus, Syria.

lead_paragraph: The Tabqa Dam, Syria’s biggest, is considered a potent weapon in the battle for allegiances in the nearly two-year-old conflict.

headline.seo: Syrian Insurgents Claim to Control Large Hydropower Dam
headline.main: Syrian Insurgents Claim to Control Large Hydropower Dam
headline.print_headline: Syrian Insurgents Claim to Control Large Hydropower Dam
